Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Short-term ozone exposure and serum neural damage biomarkers in healthy elderly adults: Evidence from a panel study.

AbstractText: Although converging lines of research have pointed to the adverse neural effects of air pollution, evidence linking ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and neural damage remains limited.
To investigate the subclinical neural effects of short-term ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) exposure in elderly adults.

A panel of healthy elderly individuals was recruited, and five repeated measurements were conducted from December 2018 to April 2019 in Xinxiang, China. Serum neural damage biomarkers, including brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), neurofilament light chain (NfL), neuron-specific enolase (NSE), protein gene product 9.5 (PGP9.5), and S100 calcium-binding protein B (S100B) were measured at each follow-up session. Personal O<sub>3</sub> exposure levels were calculated based on outdoor monitoring and sampling times. A linear mixed-effects model was adopted to quantify the acute effect of O<sub>3</sub> on serum neural damage biomarkers. Stratification analysis based on sex, education level, physical activity, and glutathione S-transferases (GST) gene polymorphism analysis was performed to explore their potential modifying effects.

A total of 34 healthy volunteers aged 63.7 ± 5.7 y were enlisted and completed the study. The concentration of the daily maximum 8-h average O<sub>3</sub> (O<sub>3</sub>-8h) ranged from 19.5 to 160.5 μg/m<sup>3</sup> during the study period. Regression analysis showed that short-term O<sub>3</sub> exposure was associated positively with serum concentrations of neural damage biomarkers. A 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> increase in O<sub>3</sub>-8h exposure was associated with an increment of 74 % (95 % CI:1 %-146 %) and 197 % (95 % CI:39 %-356 %) in BDNF (lag 2 d) and NfL (lag 1 d), respectively. The stratification results suggest that males, people with lower education levels, lower physical activity, and GST theta 1 (GSTT1)-sufficient genotype might be marginally more vulnerable.

This study provides new evidence for the neural damage risk posed by O<sub>3</sub> exposure, even at relatively low concentrations, which, therefore, requires that stringent air quality standards be developed and implemented.
